text: as overwhelming as it is to distribute
aid in a metropolis like port-au-prince
there should be less confusion in the
countryside smaller cities but that is
not the case here in the southeastern
part of Haiti the epicenter of last
Tuesday's earthquake aid has started
reaching the area but major obstacles
still stand in the way of getting food
water and shelter to those most in need
one problem is security here in the town
of leogang United States Marines
commandeered a former sugar cane factor
to help distribute about 30 tons of food
brought in by the Adri Catholic Relief
Services we allocated these these
resources to go to to come here to my
god because it's eighty to eighty-five
percent of the town has been effectively
this way the crowd outside the gate
swells with hungry people hey you don't
got your gear I'll get back here get
your gear on now I don't know how long
does it take us to get out of here my
keystrokes out of here as soon as
possible on them the Marines decide a
riot might break out and shut down
distribution with most of the food still
undelivered we bring our trucks to
continue distribution these trucks and
not as right now my my chain of command
I said that's going to be dangerous for
not only us but their people and you
can't remain here
because we can't eat this distribution
without without the scenario the truck
leaves in search of a new place the
Marines think they can secure the
desperate crowd follows the food truck
down the road my house is broken I
didn't get any rumors are another
dilemma for aid workers they didn't tell
us to come here but the rumor was they
were giving stuff away yet another crowd
of desperate people has gathered around
the office of the World Food Programme
in the small city of Jacmel they heard
on the radio that if they come to the
wfp office with a list of people in the
neighborhood in need they could get food
and possibly tense but security won't
let them know we can't find any tents
and we sleep on the street that is the
reason we come here wfe does not
distribute thanks world food program
works with food so we have we all have
to stop circulating false information
because that will create a riot in the
city the very next day a protest
demanding tents surged through downtown
Jacmel another obstacle to delivering
aid are the differing priorities between
the aid givers and the eight receivers
in order to receive food the wfp asks
that neighborhoods find a camp at a
relatively secure location off the
street out of the middle of town then
they can send representatives to come
and pick up food at distribution camps
around the area but many people in
Jacmel don't want to leave their block
this is our neighborhood we want to stay
in our neighborhood this family is
camped out on the street in front of
their crumble downtown home we have to
watch the neighborhood because we still
have houses that stand so that people
don't go and get the rest of the stuff
that we have they fear robbers will
steal their belongings if they leave
their house unprotected
is that people want to stay two meters
from their houses if the people are
staying in the streets open space not
open eyes and no roof open eyes and no
boundaries delivering food and the
street will only create chaos despite
these obstacles the World Food Programme
says it is currently feeding about
11,000 of the 60,000 people living in
the Jacmel area and that number will
continue to grow
